questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents for evaluation of a headache. The patient was in his usual state of health until several days ago, when he noted an occipital headache that has progressed and is now associated with nausea, vomiting, and fever. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and kidney transplant, for which he takes tacrolimus daily. Temperature is 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for photophobia, nuchal rigidity, and scattered petechiae over the upper and lower extremities. Based on the image below, which of the following is the most appropriate anatomical location to perform the procedure to diagnose this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This immunocompromised patient with headache, fever, and associated nuchal rigidity and photophobia most likely has meningitis. The most appropriate test to diagnose this condition is a lumbar puncture performed at the L4/L5 intervertebral space, denoted by choice D in the diagram above.  

Indications for the performance of a lumbar puncture (LP) are many, namely the evaluation of infection in the central nervous system, subarachnoid hemorrhage, central nervous system malignancies, and demyelinating disorders such as Guillain Barre syndrome. LP is generally safe; however, it is contraindicated in patients with increased intracranial pressure, bleeding diathesis, or suspected spinal epidural abscess.    

Performance of the procedure requires sterile technique and positioning the patient in either a lateral decubitus position or sitting upright. In an average adult, the spinal cord tapers and ends at the level between the L1 and L2 vertebrae. In neonates, it ends at L3, so the procedure is safely performed via needle insertion at the L4/L5 interspace in both populations. This space is most easily identified via direct palpation of the superior iliac crests and tracing an imaginary line from this point to the lumbar spine. Palpation of the lumbar spine at this location will reveal the L4/L5 spinous processes, and the area for needle insertion is between the two.  

The insertion sequence includes skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, and finally, the subarachnoid space. Once in this space, removal of the stylet will reveal the flow of cerebrospinal fluid through the proximal end of the needle.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Choice A represents the thoracic spinal vertebral interspace, which is too high to perform this procedure safely. Lumbar puncture at this interspace risks damage to the thoracic spinal cord.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Choice B represents the thoracic interspace between ribs 9 and 10. This area may be appropriate for performing a thoracentesis, not a lumbar puncture.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Choice C represents the L2 interspace, which is too high to perform a lumbar puncture safely. Performance of this procedure at this interspace risks direct injury to the spinal cord.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Choice E represents the sacrum, which does not have an interspace for the performance of a lumbar puncture.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to progressively worsening headaches. He states he was “feeling fine” until 2 weeks ago when he started having fevers, accompanied by malaise, and headache. Medical history is significant for renal transplantation from a living donor 6 months ago. Medications include tacrolimus and prednisone. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 138/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic and in distress due to pain. Neck is supple, and there are no focal neurologic signs. Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals an elevated opening pressure, elevated cell count, low glucose and high protein. Examination of the CSF shows the following:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    

Appropriate treatment is initiated. Which of the following is a side effect associated with this treatment?
questions.solution:
This immunocompromised patient is presenting with headaches, fever, and malaise; given the lumbar puncture analysis, the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is confirmed by the demonstration of clear halos on India ink staining.   

Cryptococcus neoformans is a budding, heavily encapsulated yeast (not dimorphic) that can be found in soil and pigeon droppings. It is acquired through the inhalation of spores with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the brain meninges. Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., organ transplant, HIV) are specifically at risk for infection with cryptococcus. Treatment consists of induction therapy with amphotericin B and flucytosine followed by fluconazole for the maintenance period.  

Amphotericin B is a medication used to treat systemic mycosis conditions including Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Histoplasma, Mucor, and Candida. It works by binding ergosterol (unique to fungi) and forming membrane pores that lead to leakage of electrolytes. Side effects include fever, chills, hypotension, nephrotoxicity, arrhythmias and anemia. Hydration prior to treatment is recommended as it reduces the nephrotoxic effect. Liposomal (lipid formulations) amphotericin is better tolerated. Supplements of potassium and magnesium are recommended due to depletion from altered renal tubule permeability.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of cytochrome P-450:
Incorrect: Inhibition of cytochrome P-450 is a side effect of azole medications (e.g., clotrimazole, fluconazole) which are not used in the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. Fluconazole is only used during the maintenance phase of treatment or if first-line medication is not available or not well tolerated. 
❌ Hepatotoxicity:
Incorrect: Hepatotoxicity can be seen with terbinafine used for onychomycosis (dermatophytic infection of the nails). Other side effects include gastrointestinal upset, headaches, and taste disturbance. Terbinafine is not used for cryptococcus treatment. 
❌ Histamine release:
Incorrect: Flushing caused by histamine release can be seen with echinocandins use (e.g. caspofungin). Echinocandins are used for the treatment of invasive aspergillosis and candida, not cryptococcus.
✅ Arrhythmias :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypercalcemia is associated with foscarnet, which is used to treat CMV retinitis and acyclovir-resistant HSV. Other side effects include nephrotoxicity, electrolyte abnormalities  (hypo/hypercalcemia, hypo/hyperphosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), and seizures. It has no role in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to the recent onset of seizure. Her parents report that 2 days ago, she started complaining of headaches and fever after returning from a fishing trip to Florida. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is postictal and responds only to noxious stimuli. Pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Meningeal signs are positive. Imaging results are equivocal. Lumbar puncture is obtained, and the results are shown below:  

 
 Cerebrospinal fluid 
 Opening pressure  500 mm H2O 
 Protein   250 mg/dL 
 Glucose  20 mg/dL 
 RBCs  1000 cells//mm3 
 WBC count   10000/µL 
 Neutrophils   90%  
 Lymphocytes  10% 
 Gram stain   Negative  
 Wet mount   

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with rapidly progressive headaches, fever, altered mental status, and new onset of seizure. In light of the recent fishing trip and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showing very high opening pressure, very high neutrophilic lymphocytosis, numerous RBCs and motile protozoan on wet mount, the most likely diagnosis is primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri.   

Naegleria fowleri is a protozoan parasite that can be found in fresh water sources (thermophilic amoebae) worldwide. The most common risk factor for infection is recreational water activities. Trophozoites from the water cross the cribriform plates to reach the brain. PAM is an acute hemorrhagic meningoencephalitis with an extremely high mortality rate. Patients often present with high fevers, severe headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, behavioral changes, seizures, and altered mental status. CSF analysis typically shows high WBC count with marked polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, elevated protein, numerous RBCs (due to hemorrhage) but negative routine bacterial cultures and gram stain. Diagnosis is based upon clinical suspicion and is established by observation of motile trophozoites on CSF wet mount or by polymerase chain reaction. Conventional treatment includes amphotericin B (first-line) as well as other agents. Amphotericin B is a medication used to treat systemic mycosis conditions including Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Histoplasma, Mucor, Candida, etc. It works by binding ergosterol (unique to fungi) and forming membrane pores that lead to leakage of electrolytes, and it can therefore result in adverse effects such as electrolyte disturbances and cardiac arrhythmias.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is a bactericidal antibiotic that works by forming toxic free radicals that damage the bacterial DNA. It is also used to treat some protozoal and anaerobic infections. Metronidazole is indicated for the treatment of Entamoeba histolytica but not for Naegleria fowleri infections.
✅ Amphotericin B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin is an anti-tuberculosis drug that works by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It is also indicated for meningococcal prophylaxis for close contacts. It is not indicated for primary amebic meningoencephalitis. 
❌ Pyrimethamine:
Incorrect: Pyrimethamine is a medication that interferes with the regeneration of tetrahydrofolic acid by the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. It is used for the treatment of toxoplasmosis infection, not primary amebic meningoencephalitis. 
❌ Imipenem :
Incorrect:  Imipenem is a broad-spectrum, β-lactamase-resistant carbapenem used for the treatment of gram-positive cocci or gram-negative rods, as well as anaerobes. It is usually reserved for life-threatening infections or after other drugs have failed. However, it is not indicated for the treatment of primary amebic meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old right-handed man is brought to the clinic by his parent for evaluation of "abnormal behavior.” The patient’s parent reports that the patient has been eating uncontrollably. The patient has also demonstrated inappropriate sexual behavior towards family members. Also of concern to the patient’s parent is that the patient seemed indifferent to the news that the patient’s other parent had passed away a few weeks ago. The patient’s parent denies any recent head trauma sustained by the patient but does state that the patient was hospitalized two months ago for a “brain infection.” A follow-up MRI is ordered. Which of the following parts of the brain is most likely to demonstrate abnormal findings?

choices.text: Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
Kluver-Bucy syndrome is a neurobehavioral syndrome that results from bilateral damage to the amygdala. It is characterized by three types of disinhibited behavior: increased sexual drive (hypersexuality), uncontrollable desire to eat (hyperphagia), and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Lack of emotional responsiveness, recurrent unprovoked seizures, and visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects) are other symptoms that are also seen in Kluver-Bucy syndrome.  

The most common etiology of Kluver-Bucy syndrome is viral encephalitis typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, which can damage the temporal lobes and the amygdala. The amygdaloid nuclei are located within the temporal lobes and supplied by the anterior choroidal arteries. They comprise a portion of the the limbic system, which is responsible for sexual drive as well as emotional and behavioral responses. Other causes of Kluver-Bucy syndrome include temporal lobe surgery and head trauma that results in temporal lobe contusions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome typically results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus could present with left-sided hemiballismus. Hemiballismus is an involuntary, large amplitude, unilateral movement of the limbs and most commonly results from a lacunar infarct sustained to the subthalamic nuclei.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus includes the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior right parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock), and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
✅ Bilateral amygdala:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male college student is brought to the emergency department accompanied by his roommate due to fever, headache, and altered mental status. The roommate says that the patient was healthy until 2 days ago, when he started having persistent fevers and progressively worsening headaches. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented, and nuchal rigidity is noted. Examination of the skin shows no signs of rash or lesions. Neurological examination is limited due to altered mental status. Lumbar puncture is performed and reveals low glucose, elevated protein, and leukocytosis with polymorphonuclear predominance. Gram staining shows gram-negative bacteria. Which of the following should be administered to close contacts of this patient?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy college student is presenting with a severe headache and high-grade fever. In addition, he has altered mental status and positive meningeal signs, which are all consistent with meningitis. Based on his risk factors (living in a dormitory), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, and gram stain, the most likely causative organism is Neisseria meningitidis. It is important to note that characteristic petechial rash is present only in 50% of the cases, and its absence does not rule out the diagnosis.  

Neisseria meningitidis (meningococci) is gram-negative diplococci that is capable of a variety of clinical manifestations ranging from transient fever and bacteremia to fulminant fatal disease within hours. It is the second most common cause of meningitis in adults below the age of 60 years (with S. pneumoniae being the most common). Infections typically occur in the settings of weakened immunity or crowded places with infected patients; crowded areas like military bases or college dorms allow the bacteria to spread quickly via respiratory droplets and oral secretions. Due to these features and the mortality risk, close contact requires immediate prophylaxis to prevent the spread of the infection. Close contact refers to individuals who:  

  •  spent prolonged time with an infected person (>8 hours) while in close proximity (< 3 feet) 
  •  individuals who have been directly exposed to the patient’s oral secretions 7 days prior and up until 24 hours after antibiotics treatment initiation 
Prophylactic antibiotics regimen include rifampin, ceftriaxone, and ciprofloxacin (avoided in pregnant patients and in those <18 years of age). 

Option Analysis

❌ Metronidazole :
Incorrect: Metronidazole is a bactericidal antibiotic that works by forming toxic free radicals that damage the bacterial DNA. It is also used to treat some protozoal and anaerobic infections. Although metronidazole covers gram-negative bacteria, it is not indicated for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis prophylaxis. 
❌ Vancomycin :
Incorrect: Vancomycin is an antibiotic that works by inhibiting cell wall peptidoglycan formation. It is effective against gram-positive infections only. This patient's CSF was positive for gram-negative bacteria. 
❌ Imipenem :
Incorrect: Imipenem is a broad-spectrum, β-lactamase-resistant carbapenem used for the treatment of gram-positive cocci or gram-negative rods, as well as anaerobes. It is usually reserved for life-threatening infections or after other drugs have failed. It is not indicated for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis prophylaxis. 
✅ Ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rifabutin:
Incorrect: Rifabutin is an anti-tuberculosis medication that works by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It is not indicated for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis. In contrast, rifampin, another type of anti-tuberculosis medication, can be used for meningococcal meningitis prophylaxis.
